eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian, Tristan Rhodes (https://victrisgames.itch.io/)
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: EllipseMovement
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Move objects on ellipses or smoothly back and forth in one direction.
description: It allows objects to move:
- on an ellipsis or arcs
- smoothly vertically or horizontally (by setting one radius to 0)
- on a sine wave (by adding a force)
It can be used for:
- Making objects float, such as powerups or coins
- Moving platforms
- Enemy movement patterns
- Making a player constantly turn right or left ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://star-seeker))

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Move objects on ellipses or smoothly back and forth in one direction.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: EllipseMovement

events.comment: Evaluate the center of movement from the object position and properties.
Update the center when the object is moved outside of the behavior.
Place the object according to the movement angle.
Save the position to detect when the object is moved outside of the behavior.
Update the movement angle for the next frame.

eventsFunctions.description: Change the turning direction (left or right).
eventsFunctions.name: ToggleTurningLeft

eventsFunctions.description: Change the in which side the object is turning (left or right).
eventsFunctions.name: SetTurningLeft

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the object is turning left.
eventsFunctions.name: IsTurningLeft

eventsFunctions.description: Return the movement angle of the object.
eventsFunctions.name: MovementAngle

eventsFunctions.description: Return the loop duration (in seconds).
eventsFunctions.name: LoopDuration

eventsFunctions.description: Return the ellipse radius on X axis.
eventsFunctions.name: RadiusX

eventsFunctions.description: Return the ellipse radius on X axis.
eventsFunctions.name: RadiusY

eventsFunctions.description: Return the movement center position on X axis.
eventsFunctions.name: CenterX

eventsFunctions.description: Return the movement center position on Y axis.
eventsFunctions.name: CenterY

eventsFunctions.description: Change the radius on X axis of the movement.

eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the radius on Y axis of the movement of _PARAM0_ to _PARAM2_

eventsFunctions.description: Change the loop duration.
eventsFunctions.name: SetLoopDuration
eventsFunctions.sentence: Change the loop duration of _PARAM0_ to _PARAM2_

eventsFunctions.description: Change the movement angle. The object is teleported according to the angle.
eventsFunctions.name: SetMovementAngle

propertyDescriptors.label: Radius of the movement on X axis
propertyDescriptors.name: RadiusX

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ParticleEmitter3D
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Display a large number of particles to create visual effects.
description: Particle emitters can be used to display:
- Fire
- Smoke
- Splashes
- Lights
Breaking change
- Object properties for position and rotation have been removed. They must be set with the instance editor or the action.
- Particles were 3 times too small

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: 4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Parallax
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Behaviors to animate Tiled Sprite objects in the background, following the camera with a parallax effect.
description: Behaviors to animate Tiled Sprite objects in the background, following the camera with a parallax effect.
Breaking changes
- The parallax now starts with an offset of 0.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Move the image of a Tiled Sprite to follow the camera horizontally with a parallax effect. After adding this to an object, put the object on a layer that is not moving, behind the layer that is followed (for example, a layer called "Background").
eventsBasedBehaviors.fullName: Horizontal Parallax for a Tiled Sprite
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: HorizontalTiledSpriteParallax

events.comment:
- The left side of the camera is used to have the left side of the image at X = 0 in the scene.
  This also allows the image to keep the same location when the window ratio changes.

- The camera left side is calculated for a zoom of 1 instead of using CameraBorderLeft() that use the current zoom.
  It allows the image to keep the same location when the zoom change.

(CameraCenterX(FollowedLayer) - CameraWidth(FollowedLayer) / 2 * CameraZoom(FollowedLayer)) * ParallaxFactor

When a zoom changes, the object size in the scene also change to cover the screen.
This part of the formula takes this into account:

(CameraZoom(Object.Layer()) - 1) * CameraWidth(Object.Layer()) / 2

propertyDescriptors.label: Parallax factor (speed for the parallax, usually between 0 and 1)
propertyDescriptors.name: ParallaxFactor

propertyDescriptors.label: Layer to be followed (leave empty for the base layer)
propertyDescriptors.name: FollowedLayer

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Move the image of a Tiled Sprite to follow the camera vertically with a parallax effect. After adding this to an object, put the object on a layer that is not moving, behind the layer that is followed (for example, a layer called "Background").
eventsBasedBehaviors.fullName: Vertical Parallax for a Tiled Sprite
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: VerticalTiledSpriteParallax

events.comment: See the comment in the other behavior for an explanation of this formula.

propertyDescriptors.label: Parallax factor (speed for the parallax, usually between 0 and 1)
propertyDescriptors.name: ParallaxFactor

propertyDescriptors.label: Layer to be followed (leave empty for the base layer)
propertyDescriptors.name: FollowedLayer

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: @4ian
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Bounce
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Bounce the object off another object it just touched.
description: Provides an action to make the object bounce from another object it just touched.
> ⚠️ This *won't work* with Physics engine or Platformer characters. This is working with objects that are moved using actions or behaviors using **the forces**.
The Breakout-like example uses this extension to make balls bounce ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://breakout)).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Provides an action to make the object bounce from another object it just touched. Add a permanent force to the object and, when in collision with another one, use the action to make it bounce realistically.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: Bounce

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOff

events.comment:
To bounce the object realistically, we first separate it from the obstacle. The collision engine will do it by moving the object through the shortest "normal vector" of the edge that was collided.
We store the position of the object before being moved so that we know the angle of this "normal vector". Once we know it, we add a force in the direction of the normal vector, and we add the difference between the normal vector and the previous angle of movement.

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
The bounce will always be calculated *to go toward the specified angle (the "normal angle")*. For example, if the object is arriving at this exact angle, it will bounce in the opposite direction.

Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Bounce off another object toward a specified angle
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOffSpecificAngle
eventsFunctions.sentence: Bounce _PARAM0_ off _PARAM2_ assuming a normal angle of _PARAM3_

events.comment:
Check if there is a collision between the object and an obstacle and if so, do the bounce by stopping the object and adding a force so that it goes in the "reflected" direction, using the "normal" angle provided. 
This provides a realistic bounce.

parameters.description: The "normal" angle, in degrees, to bounce against
parameters.longDescription: This can be understood at the direction that the bounce must go toward.
parameters.name: NormalAngle

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
The bounce will always be vertical, like if the object is *colliding a perfectly horizontal obstacle* (like the top/bottom of the screen in a pong game). For example, if the object is arriving with an angle of exactly 90 degrees, it will bounce in the opposite direction: -90 degrees.

Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOffVertically

eventsFunctions.description:
Bounce the object off another object it is currently colliding with, according to the angle and the speed of forces applied on the object.
The bounce will always be horizontal, like if the object is *colliding a perfectly vertical obstacle* (like paddles in a pong game). For example, if the object is arriving with an angle of exactly 0 degrees, it will bounce in the opposite direction: 180 degrees.

Make sure to test for a collision between the two objects before launching this action. All the forces will be removed from the object, and a new permanent force will be added to make the object bounce.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceOffHorizontally

eventsFunctions.description: the number of times this object has bounced off another object.
eventsFunctions.name: BounceCount

propertyDescriptors.label: Bounce count
propertyDescriptors.description: Number of times this object has bounced off another object
propertyDescriptors.name: BounceCount

description: This behavior moves an object (like an enemy) for a chosen time or distance, then flips it and starts over, moving the object back and forth, vertically or horizontally.
Note: animations must be facing **Right** (for horizontal) or **Down** (for vertical) direction.

Note: animations should be facing LEFT.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: BoidsMovement
description: Simulates swarms or flocks movement following the separation, alignment, cohesion principles. The flock can be attracted to a location or avoid some obstacles.
The [Fish School example](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://fish-school) shows how properties impact on the movement.

eventsFunctions.description: Define helper classes JavaScript code.
eventsFunctions.name: DefineHelperClasses

inlineCode: * Adds a velocity to this vector
* @param {Vector} referenceVector gets the velocity to be added
* Subtracts vectors verticies from a reference vector
* Methods for Separation, Cohesion, Alignment added
* Inspired from The Nature of Code - Daniel Shiffman
* @param {Vector} vector the vector to return the result
* Applys the three rules of boids
* Apply the acceleration from the steer force.
* Calculates and applies steering force towards a direction
* Alignment: calculate the average velocity for every nearby boid in the system
* Cohesion: calculate direction vector towards the average location of all nearby boids
// A vector pointing from the position to the target
* Add a boid to the R-Tree.
* Remove a boid from the R-Tree.
* Returns all the boids around the specified boid.
* @return {Boid[]} An array with all boids near the object.
// TODO The R-Tree should not allocate an array.
// Cap the number of boids between 20 and 40.

events.comment:
Evaluate at which distance the object will go past a location if it were to continue in its current direction.

speedUnitX = velocityX / speed
speedUnitY = velocityY / speed

deltaX = centerX - object.CenterX
deltaY = centerY - object.CenterY

normalX = -deltaY;
normalY = deltaX;

trajectoryDistance = speedUnitX * normalX + speedUnitY * normalY
If this distance is smaller than the specified radius, the Boid must try turn in the right direction to avoid the area.
(normalX ; normalY)
(-normalX ; -normalY)

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Entropy, @VictrisGames
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Boomerang
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Throw an object that returns to the thrower like a boomerang.
description: Throw an object that returns to the thrower after a length of time, or when an action is used to return it.
How to throw a boomerang:
- Create a bomerang object that has this behavior
- Use one of the "Throw boomerang..." actions
- Run the "Track location of thrower" action every frame so the boomerang returns correctly
Tips:
- If you want the boomerang to bounce off objects, check for collisions and then use the action "Send boomerang back to thrower"

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: SmoothCamera
eventsFunctionsExtensions.previewIconUrl: https://resources.gdevelop-app.com/assets/Icons/Line Hero Pack/Master/SVG/Computers and Hardware/Computers and Hardware_camcoder_gopro_go_pro_camera.svg
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
description: The camera follows an object according to:
- a frame rate independent catch-up speed to make the scrolling from smooth to strong
- a maximum speed to do linear following ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://platformer-with-tilemap)) or slow down the camera when teleporting the object
- a follow-free zone to avoid scrolling on small movements
- an offset to see further in one direction
- an extra delay and catch-up speed to give an impression of speed (useful for dash)
- position forecasting and delay to simulate a cameraman response time
A platformer dedicated behavior allows to switch of settings when the character is in air or on the floor. This can be used to stabilize the camera when jumping.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Smoothly scroll to follow an object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: SmoothCamera

events.comment: Update private properties through setters to check their values and initialize state.

eventsFunctions.description: Move the camera closer to the object. This action must be called after the object has moved for the frame.
eventsFunctions.name: MoveCameraCloser

events.comment: The camera following is called with an action, the call from doStepPreEvents must be disabled to avoid to do it twice.

eventsFunctions.description: Move the camera closer to the object.
eventsFunctions.name: DoMoveCameraCloser

events.comment:
Delaying and forecasting can be used at the same time.
Forecasting only use the positions that are older than the one used for delaying.
The behavior uses a position history that is split in 2 arrays:
- one for delaying the position (from TimeFromStart to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay)
- one for forecasting the position (from TimeFromStart - CamearDelay to TimeFromStart - CamearDelay - ForecastHistoryDuration

At each frame, the camera must catchup the target by a given ratio (speed)
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1) - targetX) * speed

The frame rate must not impact on the catch-up speed, we don't want a speed in ratio per frame but a speed ratio per second, like this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - 1s) - targetX) * speed

Ok, but we still need to process each frame, we can use a exponent for this:
cameraX(t) - targetX = (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * speed^timeDelta
cameraX(t) = targetX + (cameraX(t - timeDelta) - targetX) * exp(timeDelta * ln(speed))

pow is probably more efficient than precalculated log if the speed is changed continuously but this might be rare enough.

events.comment: Add the previous position to have enough (2) positions to evaluate the extra delay for waiting mode.
Use the object center when no delay is asked.
Remove history entries that are too old to be useful for delaying and pass it to the history for forecasting.
Don't move the camera if there is not enough history.

Add the extra delay that could be needed to respect the speed limit in waiting mode.

speedRatio = min(speedMaxX / historySpeedX, speedMaxY / historySpeedY)
delay += min(0, timeDelta * (1 - speedRatio))
The time with delay is now between the first 2 indexes

eventsFunctions.description: Update forecasted position. This is called in doStepPreEvents.
eventsFunctions.name: UpdateForecastedPosition

events.comment:
Simple linear regression
y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX

Note than we could use only one position every N positions to reduce the process time,
but if we really need efficient process JavaScript and circular queues are a must.

VarianceX = sum((X[i] - MeanX)²)
VarianceY = sum((Y[i] - MeanY)²)
Covariance = sum((X[i] - MeanX) * (Y[i] - MeanY))

y = A * x + B

A = Covariance / VarianceX
B = MeanY - A * MeanX
Axis permutation to avoid a ratio between 2 numbers near 0.
Permute back axis

eventsFunctions.description: Project history ends position to have the vector on the line from linear regression. This function is only called by UpdateForecastedPosition.
eventsFunctions.name: ProjectHistoryEnds
eventsFunctions.sentence: Project history oldest: _PARAM2_;_PARAM3_ and newest position: _PARAM4_;_PARAM5_ of _PARAM0_

events.comment:
Perpendicular line:
pA = -1/a; 
pB = -pA * x + y

Intersection:
/ ProjectedY = a * ProjectedX + b
\ ProjectedY = pA * ProjectedX + b

Solution that is cleaned out from indeterminism (like 0 / 0 or infinity / infinity):
ProjectedX= (x + (y - b) * a) / (a² + 1)
ProjectedY = y + (x * a - y + b) / (a² + 1)
